poll_list.title: Use the MakerDAO Treasury to Fund MKR Expenses - November 29, 2021

discourse_list.title: [Signal Request] Should We Mint New MKR for Protocol Expenses or Fund Them With MKR from the MakerDAO Treasury?

content.content: Overview Maker Governance has passed several budgets that include payments of MKR to Core Unit members as part of a compensation package. It is not inconceivable that other expenses denominated in MKR may become apparent in the near future. Some of the current MKR vesting schedules may be seen on Makerburn. At present, there is no clear indication about what should be the source of the MKR used for these expenses. There are two main options to source this MKR:  Use MKR from the MakerDAO Treasury - currently MakerDAO owns 83700.1 MKR that was transferred from the Maker Foundation. This is visible at the address: 0xBE8E3e3618f7474F8cB1d074A26afFef007E98FB  Mint new MKR using the PauseProxy  The purpose of this poll is to see which of these two mechanisms Maker Governance would prefer to utilise. This thread on the forum contains some discussion around this already and may make for useful reading.  Use MKR from the MakerDAO Treasury  Pros  We already own this MKR - no requirement to mint new MKR or purchase it on the open market Does not inflate MKR supply - this MKR already exists, although it is currently locked.   Cons  Governance has previously demonstrated a desire to delay spending this MKR. See thread. Some community members have called for this MKR to be burned. See this thread and this signal request. Committing to using this MKR will likely prevent this to a degree.   Mint New MKR  Pros  Familiarises people within and outside the DAO with the concept of minting MKR. Further MKR minting has been suggested in some recent proposals. Preserves the amount of MKR which the DAO owns directly for future use.   Cons  Dilutes overall MKR supply, potentially decreasing the MKR/DAI ratio. Minting new MKR potentially carries some legal and/or regulatory risk.     Should we mint new MKR for expenses or use MKR from the MakerDAO Treasury?  Mint New MKR Use Treasury MKR Abstain     0 voters      Next Steps Poll will run for two weeks until Saturday, November 27th. Following this, an on-chain vote will be held for MKR holders to confirm the decision.

Abstained because my answer is Neither. We should Make MKR vesting directly related to DAI net profits via having a MKR buy component. Example for illustration: lets say protocol makes 10M DAI net expenses during a 3 month period. We could take 5M and buy MKR and 5M to build surplus and then fund the MKR vesting.  Lets say MKR purchased averaged 5K/MKR (so we bought 1000MKR with the 50% DAI net and built the surplus with the other 50% DAI net). Lets also say only 500MKR was required for vesting during that 3 month period.  So we can do a few things.  Save the extra 500MKR for vesting when net DAI isn’t sufficient to cover vesting schedule. Burn some fraction of the 500MKR and save the rest. Burn all the 500MKR  Let say 2000 MKR was required.  We fund the MKR compensation at 50% level and ignore deficits. We fund the MKR at 50% level and save deficits to be made up with MKR purchased later.  The above model is fully sustainable because  MKR vested is tied to net DAI profit completely aligning interests of people working with MKR holders.  (how much of this profit is set aside - many different ways to manage set this) No new MKR minting is needed for DSSVest. Automatically determines the vesting price because MKR was purchased with DAI. Allows a continuous purchase of MKR based on profits vs. some arbitrary SB level and directly related to DAI profits. MKR burn happens when there is excess MKR purchased beyond needed for vesting.

content.content: This is a really intriguing post and I would be interested to see you take this further. However, there are multiple MKR vesting schedules that have already been accepted by MKR holders in the form of MIPs and these would therefore require a MIP amendment or entirely new MIP to change. This signal request aims to identify how we should fund these already accepted MKR vesting schedules and any future MKR expenses, in the absence of a complete system overhaul in the manner that you suggest.

Patrick_J:  This is a really intriguing post and I would be interested to see you take this further. However, there are multiple MKR vesting schedules that have already been accepted by MKR holders in the form of MIPs and these would therefore require a MIP amendment or entirely new MIP to change. Appreciate the sentiment but would rather someone else who is being paid decide whether this idea is worthy of being driven down the governance road. I simply don’t have the time to drive this stuff basically for ‘free’.   The basic concepts are outlined in the above. My goal has always been to try to suggest sustainable solutions to basic Maker issues.  Whether MakerDAO or anyone decides to work with me to bring them forward - well so far not many takers. Here is another example I have been waiting for @LongForWisdom to comment on before I even brought it forward regarding a general governance compensation model. In general I think there is a productivity hazard here.  …     Regarding this signal request because I have long been talking about the above I pretty much am going to abstain from these and let the DAO do whatever it wants to do with the existing vesting ‘model’.

Adding this quote from the core unit facilitator of PE as it seems relevant to our current conversation. The original DSSVest thread has a discussion about this starting from this comment by @wouter onwards. Tbh the whole thread is worth a read though.

There needs to be more incentive alignment between contractors and investors Just using MKR from the treasury isn’t a sustainable solution as it will eventually run out. As a long term fix couldn’t we create a new auction type (flap-b)? X% of the dai issued to core teams would be sent to a flap-b auction. MKR would be used to purchase the dai offered in the flap-b auction. Rather then burn MKR from the flap-b auction it would be sent to the treasury to vest until it is eventually distributed through dss-vest. This would ensure incentives are aligned between MKR holders and core teams and that we can support vesting well into the future. It also acts as a way to ‘lock up’ more MKR
NEITHER - and there should be a vote for such a choice.  See @MakerMan 's reply.  Use DAI to buy MKR on the market to satisfy such commitments/promises.  NEVER mint MKR for this purpose.

I’ve voted for the “Use Treasury MKR” option for now but I agree completely with MakerMan’s post. This should come from protocol earnings, not from minting or dipping into reserves. I’m not sure if it’s possible to make this happen for existing commitments but any future ones should go through this route.

+1, I’m in the same boat. Voted “Use Treasury”, but really like the fundamental sustainability in Makerman’s model. In drafting our own CU’s MKR comp package these things are all being noted. We want a model that makes sense for both the protocol and its contributors.

At current prices there seems to be 18M worth of MKR vested annually, so it seems doable at the current profit level. However price increases may change that picture drastically so to be really sustainable the MKR vesting may need to be denominated in profit % of the protocol. That would need to be negotiated with CUs. It sounds better than burning though! This model is very different from the usual one where shares in comp packages may create dilution. It could ultimately result in reduced MKR compensation, but it also increases the incentive to buyback across the board, which positively impacts the price, so maybe not.

Thanks everyone for the engagement. Some interesting posts have been made. @omahalawyer the rationale behind not including a “neither” option is that commitments to pay this MKR have already been made by Maker Governance. We need an actionable plan for how we are going to meet these commitments. I appreciate you’ve suggested an alternative, but in reality a mechanism to link DSSVest to the open market would require a smart contract overhaul and a MIP amendment. All of which will take time. The solutions presented in this SR are workable within the current MakerDAO systems. However, I’m not against the principle of restarting this signal with “Neither” as an option. @LongForWisdom what do you think about a restart that includes a “Neither” option?

I think you’re correct in that right now with the current tools, we need to choose between mint and treasury. I don’t think having a ‘neither’ option in this case would help much. I’d recommend not restarting it.

LongForWisdom:  I think you’re correct in that right now with the current tools, we need to choose between mint and treasury. I don’t think having a ‘neither’ option in this case would help much. I’d recommend not restarting it.   This is really the crux of the issue. I understand the technical limitations however I think as a community we should try and not use current technical limitations as a reason to justify not running a signal request. When PE initially put forth the DSS vest module their plan was to mint MKR. They justified this solution because from a technical perspective it was the easiest to implement. Based on the current signal request you can see their initial minting solution is not supported by the community. If we do not seek further clarity we are repeating the mistakes we made when governance approved the DSS Vest module in it’s current implementation. I also think the strategy of ‘let’s patch this as a band aid and we can revisit it later’ is dangerous. @wouter I’d appreciate your thoughts

Zarevok:  I understand the technical limitations however I think as a community we should try and not use current technical limitations as a reason to justify not running a signal request.   Just to be clear, this is absolutely not what I’m trying to communicate. If someone wants to run a signal to figure out the future direction we want to move in to deal with this issue, have at it. But I don’t think there is any reason we can’t fix the immediate issue and also discuss future direction. They should be separate conversations:  What is our policy on how to use the tools we have? What do we want our policy to be, and what tools do we need to support that?  The problem with mixing them is that we can end up not taking the immediate win, because we want some better solution that cannot be swiftly implemented. Like, choosing ‘good’ now doesn’t mean we can’t choose ‘perfect’ later. In my mind, this is a signal dealing with the first of these two conversations.

LongForWisdom:  They should be separate conversations:  What is our policy on how to use the tools we have? What do we want our policy to be, and what tools do we need to support that?  The problem with mixing them is that we can end up not taking the immediate win, because we want some better solution that cannot be swiftly implemented. I would absolutely agree with you if we were discussing something trivial however I feel the magnitude of this signal request merits the discussion. I don’t think it can be understated that vesting accounts for nearly 50% of the total expenses of the DAO. That being said, similar to @MakerMan I     MakerMan:  would rather someone else who is being paid decide whether this idea is worthy of being driven down the governance road. I simply don’t have the time to drive this stuff basically for ‘free’.   I look forward to seeing what the ‘perfect’ model ends up looking like.

Are you saying that the protocol has the ability presently to print MKR out of thin air and outside of a Flop auction?  Crossing my fingers the answer is no.  I am aware of prior compensation in MKR promises but assumed the promises were either based on giving up the MKR that is in treasury or buying on the open market, because I understood the protocol had no means to create MKR at the discretion of anyone or any smart contract outside of what rules/facts kick off a flop auction.  There should not be any way to print stock in the company so to speak.  In my view this is bad PR at minimum - is the only thing holding back the protocol from printing MKR for no direct value coming in the result of this signal request and on chain vote?  Or worse is there an assumption that if there wasn’t enough in treasury to satisfy the compensation promises that the protocol is already authorized to print MKR rather than buy on the market? Maybe need to change my vote to “Treasury” just to help squash the minting idea.

omahalawyer:  Are you saying that the protocol has the ability presently to print MKR out of thin air and outside of a Flop auction?   Yes, it does.     omahalawyer:  is the only thing holding back the protocol from printing MKR for no direct value coming in the result of this signal request and on chain vote? Or worse is there an assumption that if there wasn’t enough in treasury to satisfy the compensation promises that the protocol is already authorized to print MKR rather than buy on the market?   The current vesting contracts use minted MKR. If they are not replaced before the MKR can be claimed, MKR will be minted to the recipients. The list of recipients is here: makerburn.com

Yes, that is how DSSVest works. See this thread on DSSVest. Relevant quote:  MKR will be minted at the time a user calls vest. This function calls the contract to redeem the MKR award available to them at that block.

omahalawyer:  Or worse is there an assumption that if there wasn’t enough in treasury to satisfy the compensation promises that the protocol is already authorized to print MKR rather than buy on the market?   Yes, based on the current implementation. The protocol engineers who implemented DSSVest assumed they were authorized to mint MKR. I’m glad you see how problematic this is.

(checks notes on prior MKR compensation discussions - realizes didn’t take notes).   Thanks for answering my questions @LongForWisdom and @Patrick_J  .  I strongly believe it should be changed from potentially minting to buying on the open market - basically a flap set up except the MKR obtained would then be distributed to those promised it.  I understand that’s something I should have raised at the time.
@omahalawyer Just for semantics. Flop’s increase the MKR Supply Flap’s decrease the MKR Supply. This would be a flap not a flop.
Thanks.  Corrected.

Zarevok:  Yes, based on the current implementation. The protocol engineers who implemented DSSVest assumed they were authorized to mint MKR.   This isn’t what happened. At the time they made their vesting proposal, there was no MKR in the treasury, so minting would have been the only way to pay the MKR according to the vesting details. This passed governance. They later built DssVest, and proposed that it be used to vest themselves and others MKR, this also passed governance. There was something of a breakdown in communication in that not everyone realized MKR would be minted to do this, and that’s arguably our (GovAlpha’s) fault for not highlighting it in the relevant executive copy. My assumption was that everyone would realize it would be minted as that’s the only long-term sustainable policy for paying out vesting (because it works regardless of whether there is MKR in the treasury.)     omahalawyer:  Thanks for answering my questions @LongForWisdom and @mkrorbkr . I strongly believe it should be changed from potentially minting to buying on the open market - basically a flap set up except the MKR obtained would then be distributed to those promised it. I understand that’s something I should have raised at the time.   No problem, I think that is a good topic for a future discussion on how we want to handle this in the long term. But coming back to the right-now decision: The choice is between minting and taking from the treasury, if we do nothing, MKR will be minted when the vesting streams are claimed.

I think there are multiple unexplored options here. Given that MKR flaps have come back and the protocol has already burned 1.7K MKR (almost 3 months of vesting) I realized we can just use the treasury and burn.    We will exhaust treasury funds at some point - which will force governance to deal with the issue properly. For now: Given the fact, the protocol (even with current 1M/week surplus buffer expansion) is going to burn something like 75M DAI worth of MKR before the SB hits 90M, I noticed that even if MKR hits 10K we will have purchased enough MKR to cover vesting for the next year or two. So I am with you and to satisfy @LongForWisdom and GovAlpha I am going to end up supporting that MakerDAO take the MKR slated for MKR compensation out of the ‘treasury’.   Point here is at least at current run rate we have what 10-12 years (maybe 5 with current CU expense growth) until this source of MKR runs out and then governance will be forced to consider various options all of which will be related to changing the flapper to saving some MKR for compensation vs. burning it all.

Thanks.  I think at this point that is the right decision, but I believe the issue should be revisited sooner than 5 years from now - and instead have MKR for compensation purchased from the market.  Aside from what has been discussed it is easier to show actual compensation amounts/expense, and if there is an issue about affording such compensation it would be handled by generating additional income or cutting expenses or reducing MKR burn, rather than closing our eyes and printing stock from thin air.

If the purpose of distributing these MKR token is to vest participants in the core units, then I think we should use the SB to purchase MKR on the open market for vesting. Since we are currently burning a lot of MKR, and there is MKR in the treasury, then a more efficient equivalent solution would be to continue to burn MKR, and use the MKR in the treasury for vesting. Minting MKR for vesting is a worse alternative to either of these. However, in a future situation when MKR is not being burned, spending MKR from the treasury is essentially taking value from all MKR holders and putting it in the hands of the CUs. In the future, the return on investment that governance should require for vested MKR in terms of what the CUs deliver in exchange should be almost unreasonably high. It must be very strongly justified.
